nodeDataArray.text: Rationality
Types of Rationality
Epistemic Rationality
Systematically improving the accuracy of beliefs.
Example: Identifying the correct location of objects in a room.
Aim: Building accurate maps of reality (truth).
Instrumental Rationality
Systematically achieving values.
Example: Choosing actions that lead to desired outcomes.
Aim: Steering reality to achieve preferred outcomes (winning).
Truth and Winning
Truth ≠ Certainty
Increase the probability of accurate beliefs.
Winning ≠ Winning at others' expense
Values include everything cared about, including other people.
Concept of Rationality
Need for "rational" alongside "true" and "good".
Allows discussion of general features of map-territory correspondence.
Useful for noting systematic ways of thinking that produce truth or value.
Gold Standards in Rationality
Probability Theory
Laws underlying rational belief.
Universal application to evidence and belief updating.
Example: Probability that P(A) ≥ P(A,B).
Decision Theory
Laws underlying rational action.
Applicable regardless of goals and options.
Example: Bayesian decision-making.
Common Misconceptions
Popular culture vs. Bayesian rationality (e.g., Spock-like behavior).
Bayesian formalisms computationally intractable in real-world problems.
Need for practical methods to find truth and accomplish values.
Complex Issues in Rationality
Anthropic Problems
Uncertainty in the number of observers.
Newcomb-like Problems
Predictive decisions by other agents.
Practical Approach
Use simpler ideas like "truth" and "winning" when formalizations fall short.
Recognize cognitive biases and obstacles to truth.
Focus on systematically closer accuracy (map reflecting territory).
Communication and Definitions
Attach sequences of letters to concepts for communication.
Changing word meanings doesn’t change reality or prove thoughts.
Focus on good ways to think rather than arguing word definitions.
Normative Use of Rationality
Rationality should be consistent under reflection.
Rational thought should lead to consistent conclusions.
Use specific language to clarify meaning (e.g., "self-benefiting" vs. "right").
Avoid Overuse of "Rational"
Effective communication without over-reliance on the term.
Strive for understanding and clarity in thought processes.
